TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
(Financed by the Governance Cooperation Fund)  
 
 
FOR  
 
 
 ASSESSING COMMUNITY PERSPECTIVES ON  
 
 
GOVERNANCE IN THE PACIFIC 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
November 2002

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CGM  –  community governance mapping 
  FSPI  –  Foundation of the Peoples of the South Pacific International 
  PDMC  –  Pacific Developing Member Country 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by T. Mellor, Pacific Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Pacific  Strategy  for  the  New  Millennium  2000–2004  focuses  on  five  strategic 
objectives: (i) sound economic management, good governance, and public sector reform; (ii) 
private sector development; (iii) improvement of women’s welfare in the social, economic, and 
political  spheres;  (iv)  supporting  sustainable  environment  management;  and  (v)  supporting 
poverty reduction as a unifying theme.  Assistance efforts in the Pacific have focused on the role 
of governance in the economic development process. As part of these efforts, governance 
assessments have been conducted in several Pacific developing member countries (PDMCs) of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB).  
 
2.  One preliminary finding of the governance assessments is a lack of understanding 
among ordinary citizens, especially those in rural and island communities and villages, of the 
concept of governance as it is practiced at the national level. The technical assistance (TA)1 
aims to examine, through collaboration with a Pacific regional nongovernment organization, the 
role of citizens and leaders in a democracy, differences between traditional and modern forms 
of  governance,  and  strategies  to  bridge  the  identified  gaps.  The  TA  also  aims  to  raise 
awareness of the potential impact of governance on their daily lives. The TA provides input into 
the development of a Pacific governance strategy that is being formulated to guide ADB’s 
assistance strategy for the region for 2004–2007. The TA provides grassroots information on 
the community’s understanding of governance concepts as they are practiced at the level to 
complement ADB’s top-down governance assessments.            
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Good governance is key to effective economic and social development. Conversely, 
poor  governance  constrains  and  distorts  the  general  process  of  development  and  has  a 
discernable negative impact on the poorer and more vulnerable sections of society. Generally 
PDMCs are perceived as having weak governance institutions and processes. ADB recognizes 
the essential role of governance in the development process, including, at a minimum, efficient, 
effective, and responsive government. The ADB assistance strategy for the Pacific in the past 
decade has focused on assisting PDMCs to improve core government functions and public 
sector management, such as macroeconomic stability, public expenditure management, and 
certain  public  administration  reforms.  The  recent  undertaking  of  country  governance 
assessments  in  several  PDMCs  is  aimed  at  broadening  ADB  assistance  to  include  other 
aspects of governance that are important to ensure more targeted service delivery and more 
inclusive social development.  
 
4.   A  preliminary  conclusion  from  the  Pacific  governance  assessments  is  that  the 
effectiveness of government service delivery and the degree that communities participate in the 
development process are related to the compatibility of governance structures with local culture 
and  institutions.  Modern  governance  structures,  based  largely  on  the  Westminster  model, 
coexist alongside the traditional governance systems in many Pacific countries. For example, 
while the Constitution of the Fiji Islands recognizes the traditional chiefs, the role given to the 
Great Council of Chiefs in the Fiji Islands is largely symbolic and ceremonial under normal 
circumstances. Similarly, while village and district chiefs are expected to maintain law and order 
and look after the welfare of their community, little recognition is given to the chiefs in terms of 
resources or input into service delivery decisions. The communities are therefore far removed

from resource allocation decisions, which are normally made at the national level through the 
Ministry of Fijian Affairs.   
 
5.  Rural and island communities in many parts of the Pacific typically have little interaction 
with or understanding of the national government and civic institutions adopted since national 
independence. In addition, the long history and continued strength of subsistence economies 
within these communities leads to difficulties in “translation” from traditional interdependence 
structures to modern government structures which are underpinned by an independent public 
service and independent institutions. There is thus a need to (i) examine how the lack of 
connection between modern and traditional governance structures affects development efforts 
of governments and external funding agencies in order to understand the impacts on local 
communities; and (ii) identify and test participatory processes for building local awareness of 
governance concepts, giving voice to local communities, and resolving conflicts that may arise 
due to differences in modern and traditional governance structures (for example the role of 
women and youth in traditional customs vis-à-vis the modern concept of gender equality). In 
addition it is necessary to understand whether and how changes in the economic and social 
situation since independence have affected the local community and its social fabric. Unless 
these issues are understood and addressed through capacity building and education, political 
and social instability are likely to continue, jeopardizing economic development and constraining 
efforts to alleviate poverty. 
 
6.  The  Foundation  of  the  Peoples  of  the  South  Pacific  International  (FSPI)  Regional 
Secretariat, a regional nongovernmental organization with representation and operations in 
many PDMCs, is well positioned to be involved in this task. The FSPI consulted with a large 
number of stakeholders regarding the current state of political instability in the region. The FSPI 
concluded that the key to understanding the current state of governance in the region and 
opportunities for promoting good governance and equitable decision making are likely to be 
found in analyzing and targeting this rural-nonurban context. The FSPI therefore initiated a 3 
year project titled Voices and Choices: Gardening Good Governance and Democracy in the 
Pacific in early 2002. The project has received financial support from the United Kingdom’s 
Department for International Development (DFID) and New Zealand Overseas Development 
Agency (now NZAID).  
 
7.  The  first  phase  of  the  FSPI  project  involves  governance  mapping  activities  in 
communities  in  four  countries:  Fiji  Islands,  Kiribati,  Solomon  Islands,  and  Vanuatu.    This 
exercise will engage communities in analyzing their priority problems and linking these to issues 
of governance from a village perspective. It will assist local communities to identify effective 
traditional/local forms of governance that may complement modern systems (and vice versa). 
The project will help enable the communities to articulate their vision of society, community, and 
values, and how the traditional/local and national governance systems and institutions can 
improve or hinder individual and community livelihood. Later phases of the FSPI project move 
this process up to the national and regional levels, culminating in capacity building of civil 
society and development of materials for school curricula and rural communities on rights and 
obligations of citizens and leaders. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
8.  The TA will directly select the FSPI as consultant for the governance mapping exercise 
for this TA.  Governance mapping was the first phase of activities of the FSPI project (para. 7).

3 
FSPI was undertaking governance mapping in a number of countries in the first phase of the 
project, and this will also be a key input to the development of the Pacific governance strategy. 
No other organization has similar experience or could start the work quickly. The strategy will 
analyze differences and similarities between the traditional and modern models of governance 
viewed from the perspective of village communities and how they may impact development 
efforts by governments and funding agencies. This understanding is essential in formulating 
strategies and action plans that will build local awareness of governance concepts and practices 
that may affect the communities, encourage community participation in the decision making 
process at the local level, and allow local communities to partake in any decision making 
process on service provision and delivery.     
 
9.  The output of the TA is mainly a report with three parts: (i) a description of (a) the 
community governance mapping process that identifies traditional forms of governance and 
their place in the current governance structures and practices of grassroots communities, (b) the 
units of relationship including families and links with the wider society, (c) the resulting effects of 
these relationships and hierarchy within the community in terms of power, authority, and who 
benefits  and  who  does  not,  and  (d)  any  similarities  and  major  differences  across  sample 
communities within each country and across the four participating countries; (ii) identification of 
areas of complementarity and potential conflict between the two models in terms of concepts 
and practices in the country, and a description of current conflict management mechanisms in 
both systems; and (iii) analysis of tools and mechanisms, from the village perspective, that may 
be useful in reconciling/managing the differences and reinforcing the positive elements of the 
models in order to improve the relevance of the national and traditional governance institutions 
and  processes  to  grassroots  communities  (for  example  analyzing  the  appropriateness,  or 
relevance, of the decentralization model being adopted in several Pacific countries as a means 
to bring decision making closer to the communities.) The report will be an important input to the 
development  of  practical  strategies  and  activities  that  can  be  implemented  to  improve 
governance in individual Pacific countries. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  As the TA will be a collaboration between ADB and the FSPI, the methodology used by 
FSPI  for  the  first  phase  of  their  project  is  adopted  for  this  TA.  The  major  activity  is  the 
governance mapping process in a number of communities in the target countries of Fiji Islands, 
Kiribati, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu. The FSPI project team is working with the University of 
the South Pacific’s School of Law to investigate how best to facilitate governance linkages 
between the communities and the modern government institutions. The FSPI network affiliates 
in the Pacific are familiar with and regularly use participatory learning and action tools and 
processes in their community work.  
 
11.  The  mapping  exercise  will  gather  data  on  governance  pressure  points  within  the 
selected countries (for example land ownership, population pressures/urban drift, corruption, 
lack of community empowerment, lack of access to basic services) as well as traditional forms 
of governance (e.g. the Vanuatu and Kiribati approaches to consensus building) that have been 
less used in post colonial Pacific governments. This work will use participatory learning and 
action tools enabling local communities to analyze their societal structures (lines of authority, 
gender roles, etc.) and role of leaders in the community, and identify gender and youth related 
issues. Mapping will also identify knowledge and use of traditional and modern systems of 
problem solving and decision making to identify gaps and the relative effectiveness of each 
system.

4 
12.  The mapping exercise will enable communities to assess their own local institutional 
structures and governance challenges (for example the chiefs vis-à-vis elected members of 
Parliament), and identify effective mechanisms for promoting good governance and positive 
citizen engagement. The TA will use data gathered in the mapping process to recommend 
strategies to enhance community participation in political decision making processes relating to 
government resource allocation and service delivery and assist in improving the governance 
environment in the Pacific. 
 
C.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $200,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis by the Governance Cooperation Fund, supported by the Government of Canada. 
Detailed cost estimates and financing are provided in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The Suva-based FSPI will be directly 
selected as consultant. The project team leader is a full-time staff of FSPI and will direct the 
efforts of the teams in the four countries where communities agree to participate. Community 
mapping activities will be facilitated and coordinated by staff of FSPI affiliate organizations 
active in the selected countries. Progress reports and the final report to ADB will be prepared by 
the project team leader. Quality assurance of the methodology of community mapping and PLA 
tools, and analytical assessment of the results will be provided by FSPI partners in this project, 
including  the  Law  School  of  the  University  of  the  South  Pacific;  the  State,  Society  and 
Governance  in  Melanesia  Centre  of  the  Australian  National  University,  Australia;  and  the 
Regional Rights and Resources Team.     
 
15.  The TA will commence in January 2003 and is expected to be completed by June 2003.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Government of Canada through the Governance Cooperation Fund for 
Assessing Community Perspectives on Governance in the Pacific, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
